Coal is widely regarded as one of the safest energy sources when it comes to this metric. Studies, including those from the International Energy Agency and the World Health Organization, have shown that coal has a death rate of approximately **0.03 to 0.2 deaths per TWh**. What's important to note is that these numbers include all incidents over the entire lifecycle of each energy source — from mining and processing to operation and waste disposal. When we look at the actual number of deaths per unit of energy produced, coal comes out ahead.

This isn't to say that coal doesn't have environmental issues — it absolutely does. But when it comes strictly to the number of deaths per unit of electricity generated, coal is the safer option. It's a clear, factual comparison that shows why many countries still rely on coal as a vital part of their energy mix.
